<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_init:
```c
int metal_init(const struct metal_init_params *params)
{
	int error = 0;

	if (_metal.common.ref_count++ != 0)
		return 0;

	memset(&_metal, 0, sizeof(_metal));

	_metal.common.log_handler   = params->log_handler;
	_metal.common.log_level     = params->log_level;

	metal_list_init(&_metal.common.bus_list);
	metal_list_init(&_metal.common.generic_shmem_list);
	metal_list_init(&_metal.common.generic_device_list);

	error = metal_sys_init(params);
	if (error)
		return error;

	++_metal.common.ref_count;
	return error;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No compiler language extensions are used in the supplied code fragment. I checked for common compiler-specific extensions that are explicitly documented as extensions (and would violate MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2), including but not limited to: GCC/Clang __attribute__ or __extension__ markers, __builtin_ functions, typeof, asm/__asm__ or inline assembly, pragma directives with nonstandard extensions, Microsoft calling-convention keywords (e.g. __stdcall, __cdecl), vendor-specific storage-class specifiers, or other nonstandard keywords. The code only uses standard C constructs: function definition with pointer parameter, pre/post-increment, struct member access, memset from the C library, and returns. Note: the identifier _metal uses a leading underscore; that is a reserved-identifier concern under the C standard but is not a compiler language extension and therefore is outside the scope of Rule 1.2 as requested.
